awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Particles and Proxies for Sampling
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses sampling in high dimensions which is important for a variety of disciplines, including computational chemistry, materials science, and molecular dynamics simulations for climate models, power network, traffic models, or the study of viruses and pandemics. The project will develop new simulation algorithms as well as improvements of existing algorithms. The outcomes will benefit these disciplines in several ways. First, the algorithmic optimizations will provide new tools that practitioners could use to accelerate their computations. Second, rigorous results on these methods will provide practitioners with confidence in their predictions. Finally, open source software will be developed. Students will be involved and receive interdisciplinary training.
 
The project addresses challenges in sampling and related problems arising from complex energy landscapes such as in potential energy in an atomistic system; the negative log-likelihood in a Bayesian inference problem; or the loss function in a machine learning problem. In Markov Chain Monte Carlo methods, these landscapes often define the evolution of a Markov chain that samples some target distribution. This project will develop efficient computations of ergodic averages over Markov chains and methods that reduce the computational cost of ergodic averages, by either reducing the number of required iterations or reducing the per-iterate cost. The new techniques and analyses will be based on proxy landscapes and interacting particle systems. Proxies can reduce per-iterate cost or lead to faster convergence, while interacting particle systems can reduce the bias from proxies or cut down on variance. The project includes a study of how parameter choices affect the variance of the weighted ensemble particle method at finite particle number; the development of a weight-corrected particle system to account for bias from proxies; and an analysis of methods for overcoming sampling difficulties associated with rough landscapes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focuses on advancing computational methods to address challenging sampling problems, particularly in computational chemistry, with applications in Bayesian inversion, machine learning, and beyond. The overall goal is to improve efficiency and accuracy in computations involving complex systems, using techniques including proxy models, interacting particles, and data-driven approaches.

Highlights of the Project

  1. Development of New Techniques for Post-Analysis of Weighted Ensemble (WE) Data
    WE data is comprised of short trajectory snippets with associated importance weights. The project introduced three new methods for calculating critical quantities such as equilibrium and non-equilibrium averages, mean first passage times (MFPTs), and committor functions:

    • Fast Committor Machine (FCM):
      Leveraging new insights from machine learning, this method extends supervised learning to semi-supervised contexts. Using a novel kernel ansatz and cutting edge randomized numerical linear algebra methods, FCM demonstrated superior accuracy and speed over traditional artificial neural networks (ANNs), even with millions of samples. This approach bridges computational chemistry and cutting-edge machine learning techniques.

    • Featurized Koopman Mode Decomposition (FKMD):
      This method enhances kernel Koopman Mode Decomposition by using delay embedding and AGOP-based feature learning. It resolves dimensionality challenges from delay embedding by performing a type of whitening transformation that enforces isotropic changes in spacetime. FKMD showed significant improvements in predictive accuracy for complex dynamical systems, such as high-dimensional Lorenz models and cancer-related cell signaling problems.

    • RiteWeight:
      A stochastic approximation method for refining equilibrium and non-equilibrium averages, RiteWeight iteratively cycles through macrostate choices to enhance accuracy beyond traditional Markov State Models (MSMs). Tested on the Trp-cage miniprotein, this method delivered refined estimates at finer scales.

  2. Advances in Weighted Ensemble Theory and Implementation
    Weighted ensemble methods have been an important tool for estimating rate constants in computational chemistry. This project provided:

    • A rigorous mathematical framework revealing optimal WE parameters, allowing for more faster computation of local MFPTs and variance.
    • Novel implementation strategies for bin definitions, potentially resulting in more accurate simulations and mitigating risks of misleading results.

    These advancements can lead to order-of-magnitude improvements in WE performance, paving the way for scalable applications in fields like drug design.

  3. Coarse-Graining and Mori-Zwanzig Theory Applications
    Addressing the challenge of spatial coarse-graining in high-dimensional systems, this project leveraged Markov renewal processes (MRPs) and data-driven Mori-Zwanzig approaches to create:

    • Practical tools for reducing coarse-graining errors.
    • Improvement over MSMs in simple test systems.
    • Theoretical proofs confirming the exactness of Mori-Zwanzig equations and MRP representations.

  4. Benchmark Development for Bayesian Inversion
    To compare cutting-edge methods across disciplines, the PI proposed a benchmark for Bayesian inversion of partial differential equations (PDEs). This benchmark balances complexity and tractability, offering:

    • Precise posterior statistics and convergence metrics.
    • An open-source implementation accessible to the scientific community.
    • A benchmark that is easy enough to reproduce, yet hard enough to show real challenges in Bayesian inverse problems. 

Training and Impact

The project trained graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, fostering expertise in areas like machine learning, data analysis, and stochastic modeling. In particular, the PI's Ph.D. student, Mats Johnson, gained proficiency in PyTorch and machine learning techniques while earning his PhD at Colorado State University.

The contributions of this project extend beyond computational chemistry. Its methods and theoretical insights address fundamental challenges in stochastic modeling, offering tools that could eventually help revolutionize applications such as in-silico drug design. By advancing both theoretical frameworks and practical implementations, this project lays a foundation for broader adoption of these methods, as well as future innovations in computational science.
